title.narrative: IJR, Institute for Justice and Reconciliation Kärnstöd 2012-2016

description.narrative: The Institute for Justice and Reconciliation (IJR), based in South Africa, contributes to post-conflict stability, good goverance and human security in Africa through programmes that promote political reconciliation and social and economic justice. IJR receives core support from Sida for 2012-2015.

The Institute for Justice and Reconciliation (IJR), med bas i Sydafrika, bidrar till stabilitet i post-konfliktsituationer, god samhällsstyrning och mänsklig säkerhet i Afrika, genom program som främjar politisk försoning och social och ekonomisk rättvisa. IJR får organisatoriskt stöd från Sida för 2012-2015.

The overall objective of the IJR is “Shaping national approaches to transitional justice and reconciliation in Africa by drawing on community engagement as well as macro-trend research and comparative analysis”. More specifically, IJR has the following medium-term objectives for the 2012-2015 period: - Policy processes are influenced by research, analysis and diverse community perspectives - Stakeholders gain and use knowledge about justice and reconciliation - Platforms are created where personal and historical perspectives are acknowledged, prejudices challenged and inclusive narratives explored - Divided communities are engaged in dialogue to overcome sources of conflict - Democratic, fair and inclusive practices guide the Institute’s processes, policies and operations.

description.narrative: IJR’s work is to great extent process-oriented and is therefore difficult to firmly attribute change to particular interventions. Some examples of contribution impact can be identified and summarized as follows: IJR has played a relevant and supportive role to its focal regions, providing technical and advisory support to governmental bodies’ work in addressing transitional justice and reconciliation, including South Africa, Burundi, Zimbabwe and Kenya. For example, IJR has provided technical expertise in the formulation of the guiding principles for the Zimbabwean Transitional Justice Policy and Practice. As a direct result from an international justice conference co-hosted by IJR and their partners, the Transitional Justice Working Group in Zimbabwe was established by 46 Zimbabwean human rights NGOs, providing a platform for civil society stakeholders and the official transitional justice process. Moreover, IJR has increased the interaction with the public through increased social media interaction and through public events. In addition, IJR has provided training for 35 governmental and civic actors in transitional justice; held regional workshops allowing for civic actors, youth activists and students from the Great Lakes region to network, strategize, overcome prejudice and gain knowledge on regional reconciliation which has multiplied in interventions from participants; workshops for women leaders in grassroots movements, generating networks for increased regional collaboration and reconciliation; the establishment of the Pan-African Reconciliation Network (PAREN) as a result of increased engagement with the AU, providing a network for academics, policy actors, civil society members and peacebuilding practitioners to share and discuss issues relating to transitional justice and reconciliation initiatives on the continent; increased capacity of key government departments and civil society actors in post-conflict countries in the SADC region to promote reconciliation and transitional justice at regional, national and community levels; learning and sharing from successful country-specific programs have been developed to fit other partner countries’ local contexts; publishing 89 resources in the form of manuals, multi-media resources, reports etc. IJR has conducted workshops and held discussion fora, facilitating discussions between community groups who tend to be put in opposition to one another to help overcome prejudice and to foster positive perceptions of the other. The Gender Justice and Reconciliation program focused on LGBTQIA+ rights; the Schools’ Oral history project helped an older generation having experienced the apartheid regime discuss their experiences and thereby feel rehumanized by telling own stories, helping with closure and addressing their woundedness. Through the youth program, IJR has worked intensively with 120 youth + 360 youths more generally in South Africa to challenge the perception of the other, and workshops in Burundi addressed the role of youth in peacebuilding, regional reconciliation and social cohesion. IJR has incorporated new human resources and staff practices providing monthly learning seminars, being a forum for discussion where issues addressed externally are also addressed internally, in addition to providing learning and sharing between the different staff sections.
